conclusion: Initial state shows objects A and B suspended, and objects C, D, E, and F as solid blocks on a surface.
Objects A and B move through the air and are placed down at the locations of C, D, E, and F.
Objects A and B come into contact with C, D, E, and F due to gravity.
Final image shows objects A and B as flexible materials and objects C, D, E, and F as rigid blocks.
Flexible material placed on rigid objects will drape over and conform to the shapes of the rigid objects and the underlying surface.
Objects A and B, which appear to be flexible materials, are in an elevated position. Objects C, D, E, and F are rigid blocks situated on a surface.
C and D are located near each other, and E and F are located near each other.
Objects A and B are moved and lowered through the air towards the location where blocks C, D, E, and F are situated.
As A and B reach the surface and encounter blocks C, D, E, and F, gravity pulls the flexible material downwards.
Objects A and B will drape over and settle around the shapes of blocks C, D, E, and F.
The blocks will support the material above the surface, while the material will fall and potentially fold or wrinkle in the areas not supported by the blocks.
Objects A and B will rest on the surface, with sections of their material conforming to the shapes of the blocks C, D, E, and F underneath them.
Creating raised forms where the blocks are located, and potentially sagging or folding elsewhere on the table surface.
